Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research - Ocean Acidification Category 1: Interactive Effects of Temperature, Nutrients, and Ocean Acidification on Coral Physiology and Calcification
Award.AbstractNarration: Atmospheric and sea surface CO2 concentrations are expected to continue to increase substantially over the coming decades resulting in warmer and more acidic oceans, which will greatly stress the health of coral reefs. In addition, ocean margins where most corals live will also see continued increases in human-produced nutrient inputs. While there has recently been a considerable focus on how ocean acidification (due to higher CO2 alone) could negatively impact the growth of reef-building corals due to the projected loss in calcification, the combined impacts of CO2, temperature, and nutrients on coral physiology and calcification are poorly understood. This project will investigate the possible synergistic and antagonistic effects of elevated temperature, CO2, and nutrients on the physiology and internal calcifying chemistry of several species of corals in a laboratory setting. Research tools will include the assessment of coral energy reserves and metabolic demand, symbiotic algal physiology and molecular diversity, coral calcification, and direct measurement of the internal coral pH and carbonate concentration via microprobes. The results from this project have the potential to supply broad scientific impacts regarding how (or if) reef-building corals will survive future climate change scenarios, and will help establish several parameter ranges that could be used to strengthen ocean acidification and coral reef growth models. Likewise, broader impacts toward further education will include the professional development of two postdoctoral scholars, two PhD graduate students, and several undergraduate students. This project will also enhance scientific and technological understanding by several public outreach efforts, including participation and research education in the Young Ocean Explorers program at the Batelle Discovery Center in Ohio, the annual Coast Day public open house at the University of Delaware, as well as advisement in the National Ocean Science Bowl in Georgia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean uptake of CO2 from the atmosphere has acidified seawater, that is reducing the ocean's pH and carbonate saturation state. This process is popularly called ocean acidification (OA).  As the health of coral reef is threatened by OA, understanding how coral calcification will respond to OA is critical.  So far we have limited understand of this in part because in the past we have only measured pH inside coral calcification fluid (CF) and a critical second parameter is missing. Through this project, my group for the first time measured full depth profiles of pH and carbonate ion. Very high pH and carbonate ion concentration were measured inside CF.  This result supports the proton pumping mechanism proposed previously.  It also confirms directly that CO2 diffusion into the CF is an important source of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) for calcification. However, our results and calculation also suggest that corals achieve high internal carbonate saturation state by maintaining a very high pH but a low DIC. This should have important ramifications for predicting corals may respond to future OA.

Three postdocs and two graduate students have involved in this work, benefiting education.  Learned knowledge has been applied to teaching and seminars as well as public talks. Several manuscripts are in various stages of preparation.


Last Modified: 08/01/2015
Modified by: Wei-Jun Cai

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Ocean uptake of CO2 from the atmosphere has acidified seawater, that is reducing the ocean's pH and carbonate saturation state. This process is popularly called ocean acidification (OA). As the health of coral reef is threatened by OA, understanding how coral calcification will respond to OA is critical. So far we have limited understand of this in part because in the past we have only measured pH inside coral calcification fluid (CF) and a critical second parameter is missing. Through this project, my group for the first time measured full depth profiles of pH and carbonate ion. Very high pH and carbonate ion concentration were measured inside CF. This result supports the proton pumping mechanism proposed previously. It also confirms directly that CO2 diffusion into the CF is an important source of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) for calcification. However, our results and calculation also suggest that corals achieve high internal carbonate saturation state by maintaining a very high pH but a low DIC. This should have important ramifications for predicting corals may respond to future OA. Three postdocs and two graduate students have involved in this work, benefiting education. Learned knowledge has been applied to teaching and seminars as well as public talks. Several manuscripts are in various stages of preparation. Last Modified: 08/01/2015 Submitted by: Wei-Jun Cai
